EcmaScript6 Examples - let

The let keyword came to EcmaScript6 to replace the var keyword. The var keyword was used to declare variables until EcmaScript5, but it had a problem which was that var doesn't respect the scope and it was responsible of a lot of mistakes. The let variable respects the scope, and it solve the problem of scope with variables in EcmaScript.

Let's see an example: 

                
                    var sum_es5 = function(){
                        var a = 5;

                        if(a === 5){
                            a = 6;
                            console.log(a);
                        }


                        console.log(a);
                    }

                    sum_es5();

Using var in EcmaScript5 the variable "a" doesn't respect the scope, and the number 6 is printed in console twice. The var keyword put all declarations of variables on top of function because of that doesn't exist scope to these variables. In this example in specific the variable "a" will be always one unique variable. 

                
                    var sum_es6 = function(){
                        let a = 5;

                        if(a === 5){
                            let a = 6;
                            console.log(a);
                        }


                        console.log(a);
                    }

                    sum_es6();

Using let in EcmaScript6 the variable "a" respects the scope, and the numbers 6 and 5 are printed in console consequently. How let keyword respects the scope then this example has two variables "a" each one in its scope, and because of that the values are printed correctly.
